ACLU Voters are changing the narrative.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
Become an ACLU voter

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Did you read in Politico about the Granite Stater who asked Joe Biden about ending mass incarceration, which sparked a national question on his death penalty stance? Or did you see the questions in Portsmouth and Somersworth to Kamala Harris and Kirsten Gillibrand about a federal third gender marker?

These are just three examples of a bold new, non-partisan program, called Rights for All, that we first launched here in New Hampshire but is now nationwide. Our goal is a big one: we want to make civil rights just as prominent of an issue this presidential election as jobs, healthcare, and the economy. This starts by getting candidates on the record talking about civil rights issues. To do this, ACLU Voters are going to events and asking candidates in both parties the hard questions about immigration, LGBTQ+ rights, voting rights, criminal justice reform, privacy, and reproductive rights.

We need YOU to make a difference in this campaign.

Sign up to become an ACLU Voter volunteer and ask a presidential candidate about their position on a key issue. You'll get training on how to attend the events, what questions to ask, how to interact with candidates, and how to get the answer to your question on the record.

Sign up to be an ACLU voter who holds candidates accountable!

New Hampshire has a unique voice in our nation's politics. Help us amplify that voice to promote a better, more fair democracy.

Best,

Devon Chaffee
Executive Director, ACLU of New Hampshire
